isaInvestigation.title: Investigation
isaInvestigation.description: Created using the MetaboLights Online Editor (MOE)

studies.title: The Immediate Metabolomic Effects of Whole Genome Duplication in the Greater Duckweed Spirodela polyrhiza
studies.description: We use untargeted metabolomics to investigate the immediate phytochemical effects of autopolyploidy on our model system, the greater duckweed Spirodela polyrhiza, a small aquatic macrophyte from the family Lemnaceae. We compare metabolite abundances in four genetically distinct diploid-autotetraploid pairs to address potential implications for establishment and combine traditional dry mass normalization with nuclear density information to investigate the link with gene dosage. We found that autopolyploidy increases metabolite levels per cell, although there is considerable variation in the response of individual metabolites. However, the impact on metabolite level per biomass is limited because the increased cell size reduces metabolite concentration per cell. Nevertheless, whole genome duplication (WGD) still exerts a discernible quantitative and qualitative influence on the phytochemical composition of our strains, each with potential ecological implications. While some metabolite levels are consistently higher in all tetraploids, many effects are restricted to a single strain, reflecting the importance of genetic background.

publications.title: The immediate metabolomic effects of whole‐genome duplication in the greater duckweed, Spirodela polyrhiza.
publications.authorList: Tian Wu, Quinten Bafort, Frederik Mortier, Fabricio Almeida‐Silva, Annelore Natran, Yves Van de Peer

protocols.name: Sample collection
protocols.description:
To study the immediate effects of genome doubling in the absence of the confounding effects of both genome merging (causing increased heterozygosity and other hybridization effects) and evolution subsequent to WGD, we used diploids and stable neocolchitetraploids of the model system Spirodela polyrhiza (Anneberg et al., 2023a, b; Bafort et al., 2023; Wu et al., 2023; Turcotte et al., 2024). The details of the exact materials we used have been described elsewhere (Bafort et al., 2023). Briefly, 4 diploid strains of Spirodela polyrhiza (Landolt No. 0013, 9242, 9316, and 9346) were acquired from the Landolt collection in Zurich, Switzerland (recently moved to IBBA-CNR, Milan, Italy). Each of these strains represents a clonal lineage and is affiliated with a distinct population genetic cluster (Xu et al., 2019). Artificial neotetraploids of these 4 diploid strains were created using the colchicine protocol of Wu et al. (2023), and the stability of these lines was ascertained by flow cytometric monitoring for a minimum of 2 months after recovery.


We started a clonal culture from each of the 4 diploid and corresponding autotetraploid strains, beginning with a single frond to ensure genetic homogeneity. The plants were grown in Hoagland’s E-medium (Cross, 2002) on temperature-controlled shelves at 24 °C with 16 h light/8 h dark at 40-45 µmol/m^2/s photosynthetic photon flux density. Once these cultures had obtained sufficient biomass, 8 plants of each culture were transferred to 8 random wells spread over 11 six-well plates. After 7 days of growth under the aforementioned growth conditions, approximately 50 mg/fresh mass from each well was harvested, patted dry with paper tissue, transferred to preweighed microcentrifuge tubes with 2x 4-mm stainless steel beads, and flash frozen in liquid nitrogen.

protocols.name: Extraction
protocols.description:
Frozen plant material was ground into powder using a bead beater (MM301, Retsch Co., Hann, Germany) at 20 Hz for 1 min. Following the addition of 1 mL of HPLC-grade methanol (methanol:water, 9:1, v/v), the sample was incubated for 30 min at room temperature in a thermomixer (1000 rpm). The resulting mixture was centrifuged at 21,300 x g for 5 min. The pellet was dried at 60 °C for dry mass determination; the supernatant, containing the extracted compounds, was placed in 2 microcentrifuge tubes (900 µL for LC-MS analysis, 100 µL for GC-MS). The solvent in both tubes was removed at 37 °C under reduced pressure using a SpeedVac system, then the dry samples were sent to the VIB Metabolomics Core Ghent for further profiling, data processing and annotation (https://metabolomicscore-gent.sites.vib.be/en). In total 5 quality control (QC) samples were prepared by pooling equal volumes of all samples.


For LC-MS analyses, the dried methanol fraction was dissolved in 150 µL cyclohexane and 150 µL Milli-Q water, then vortexed and centrifuged at 21,300 x g at room temperature for 5 min. Finally, 110 µL of the water phase was filtered through a 0.22-µm filter and analyzed by reversed-phase LC-MS analysis. Light exposure was minimized as much as possible to prevent photoconversion.


For GC-MS analyses, the residue from the metabolite extraction was trimethylsilylated using 100 µL of derivatization mixture [N-methyl-N-(trimethylsilyl)trifluoroacetamide–pyridine, 5:1].

protocols.name: Chromatography
protocols.description:
Following LC-MS sample preparation, 10 µL of the extract was injected twice on a Waters Acquity Ultra Performance Liquid Chromatography (UPLC) system coupled to a Waters Synapt XS mass spectrometer (Waters Corp., Wilmslow, UK) equipped with an electrospray ionization (ESI) source operating in negative (ESI-) and positive ionization mode (ESI+). Chromatographic separation was performed on an ACQUITY UPLC BEH C18 column (2.1 mm x 150 mm, 1.7 µL; Waters Corp.) maintained at 40 °C. A gradient of two buffers was used for chromatographic separation: buffer A (H2O:acetonitrile:formic acid, 99:1:0.1, pH 3) and buffer B (acetonitrile:H2O:formic acid, 99:1:0.1, pH 3). Buffer A started at 99% A and 1% B, and was then decreased to 50% A over 30 min and further decreased to 30% A from 30 to 35 min, and finally to 0% A from 35 to 37 min. Buffer B was then kept at 100% for 2 min. Finally, buffer A was increased to 99% over 1 min and held for 5 min. The flow rate was set to 350 µL/min. 


For the GC-MS analyses, an Agilent 7890B GC system coupled to a 7250 GC/QTOF mass detector was used (Agilent, Santa Clara, CA, USA). A 1 µL sample was injected in splitless mode onto a VF-5ms capillary column (30 m x 0.25 mm x 0.25 µm; Varian CP9013; Agilent) at a constant helium flow rate of 1.2 mL/min. After injection, the oven was held at 80 °C for 1 min, ramped to 280 °C at 5 °C/min, held at 280 °C for 10 min, ramped to 320 °C at 5 °C/min, then held at 320 °C for 10 min. The MS transfer line, the MS ion source, and the quadrupole were set to 280, 230 and 150°C, respectively. The MS detector was operated in EI mode at 70 eV. Full EI-MS spectra were generated for each sample by scanning the m/z range of 50-800 with a solvent delay of 7.8 min. All biological samples were analyzed randomly, and pooled samples were included for system reproducibility.

protocols.name: Mass spectrometry
protocols.description:
All biological samples were analyzed randomly, and pooled samples were included for system reproducibility. Maximum fragmentation coverage was achieved using all ion fragmentation (MSe). For negative and positive ionization, the capillary voltage, sampling cone, and extraction cone settings were set to -2.5 kV, -37 V and -3.5 V and 2.5 kV, 40 V and 3.5 V, respectively. The source and desolvation temperatures in both modes were maintained at 120 and 400 °C. The cone gas flow rate was set to 50 L/h in both ionization modes, whereas the desolvation gas flow rates were set to 550 L/h in ESI- mode and 500 L/h in ESI+ mode. In full MS analysis, collision energy values fluctuated between 4-3 V in negative ionization mode and between 6-4 V in positive mode. For data-dependent acquisition MS/MS analysis (DDA MS/MS), an energy ramping approach was implemented, ranging from 10 to 20 eV for low-mass ions and from 20 to 45 eV for high-mass ions.


For the GC-MS analyses, an Agilent 7890B GC system coupled to a 7250 GC/QTOF mass detector was used (Agilent, Santa Clara, CA, USA). A 1 µL sample was injected in splitless mode onto a VF-5ms capillary column (30 m x 0.25 mm x 0.25 µm; Varian CP9013; Agilent) at a constant helium flow rate of 1.2 mL/min. After injection, the oven was held at 80 °C for 1 min, ramped to 280 °C at 5 °C/min, held at 280 °C for 10 min, ramped to 320 °C at 5 °C/min, then held at 320 °C for 10 min. The MS transfer line, the MS ion source, and the quadrupole were set to 280, 230 and 150 °C, respectively. The MS detector was operated in EI mode at 70 eV. Full EI-MS spectra were generated for each sample by scanning the m/z range of 50-800 with a solvent delay of 7.8 min. All biological samples were analyzed randomly, and pooled samples were included for system reproducibility.

protocols.name: Data transformation
protocols.description:
LC-MS chromatographic data were processed using Progenesis QI 2.4 (Waters Corp.). Raw data were imported with a filter strength parameter of 1. Pooled samples were used for data alignment, system reproducibility and DDA MS/MS acquisition. Peak detection was based on the results of all analytical runs, and sensitivity settings were set to maximum (5).


Normalization was done by sample dry mass (Morreel et al., 2006). All detected features, in both negative and positive ionization modes, were aligned across the chromatograms.


GC-MS peaks were detected and aligned using Profinder software (Agilent), using a minimum peak height of 300 counts and a minimum ion count of 5 peaks for feature extraction. For alignment, a retention time tolerance of 0.05 min and a minimum dot product of 0.8 were used. After alignment, only compounds with a minimum match factor evaluation (MFE) score of 0.7 in at least two replicates of a given sample group were retained.

protocols.name: Metabolite identification
protocols.description:
The profiled LC-MS features were structurally annotated using MS?FINDER v3.56 (Tsugawa et al., 2016). MassBank, GNPS, ReSpect, and in-house database PhytoFrag were used for spectral matching. The following databases were used for formula prediction and structural elucidation by in silico fragmentation: LipidMAPS, DrugBank, FoodDB, PlantCyc, chEBI, T3DB, NPA, NANPDB, COCONUT, KNApSAcK, PubChem, UNPD and an in-house database, PhytoComp. Parameter settings were precursor mass tolerance of 10 ppm; fragment mass tolerance of 10 ppm; and selected elements were C, H, N, O, P and S. Structural matches with a minimum match score of 6 were retained.


For GC-MS, the chromatograms were deconvoluted using Masshunter Unknown Analysis software (Agilent), and the metabolites corresponding to the deconvoluted spectra were matched against the NIST20 mass spectral library (https://chemdata.nist.gov/) for tentative identification. Spectral matches with a minimum match score of 80 were retained.
